title: For Sale:  Colt Model 1860 Army .44 Caliber Black Powder Revolver
postcontent: *** PENDING  SALE ***: Unfired, Pietta made Colt 1860 Army .44 caliber, percussion revolver - 1st production run example. This rare version features a brass Navy style grip; 3 screw frame - not cut for shoulder stock; round, rebated cylinder, and recoil shield capping cutout not channeled. There were fewer than 100 of this variation believed to have been made before the larger, longer grip and cut frame became standard. NOT AVAILABLE FROM RETAIL OR ON-LINE SOURCES. References to this model can be found in UNITED STATES MILITARY SMALL ARMS 1816-1865 (1970); SAMUEL COLT PRESENTS (1961) and COLT SINGLE ACTION From Patersons To Peacemakers (2006) The asking price is more than reasonable…and firm. Shipping is $20.00 nationwide. Thanks for stopping by and looking.

title: For Sale:  1800's Belgian Parlor Pistol
postcontent:
For sale/trade is a Belgian Parlor Pistol from the 1800's. It has been looked at by a proffesional and he has confirmed that it is most likely Belgian. There are no markings except 2 notches carved on the under side of the barrel. The very tip of the hammer was broken off a long time ago. Send me an offer! Willing to ship.

Parlor pistols and rifles (zimmerschutzen from German, "room marksman" or "room shoot") were popularized in the mid to late 19th Century, particularly in the Germanic countries, as a way to entertain guests, have family fun, and to increase one's shooting skills. Generally heavy barreled and often elaborately engraved rifles (zimmerbusche) were produced for clearly upscale clients. These generally used a Flobert (CB-Cap) cartridge chambered a few inches from the muzzle. Sometimes equally elaborate parlor pistols (zimmerpistole) were chambered for Flobert cartridges or simply used a percussion cap. In this country, a small, almost toylike parlor pistol was briefly manufactured by Remington in 1860.

Call or (preferably) Text- (5 one 7) five 8 1-3 four two 8

title: For Sale:  Sig 522 *FINAL PRICE DROP - MUST GO*
postcontent:
This is a time limited, going out of town and have to sell it before I do, price drop. If I have not sold it by 10am on Sunday June 3, 2012 then this price will be void.

Sig 522 for sale. Bought new, a little over a year old, good condition except for what is mostly a cosmetic issue. 

I was trying to do a modification to the storage tube inside of the 'gas block' (its not really a gas block and is purely aesthetic, its what would be the gas block on the sig 556) to mount a laser sight in there. Unfortunately, I sheered off a screw tap and haven't been able to get it out due to lacking the proper tools to do so. I also had to cut the storage tube off to allow the front end piece to be snapped back into place as a result. The end result of this whole thing is there is a screw tap snapped off inside of the cosmetic-only " gas block " and it no longer has a storage tube. When the front end-cap is in place, you can't tell that anything is wrong.

Function is flawless and I would never have attempted the above if there were any chance that it would effect function. With the proper tools it shouldn't be hard to get the tap out and finish the mod. A cheap laser sight to use for that purpose is included and is mounted on the front rail.

Also includes a foregrip and a total of 3 Sig 26 round magazines and a BSA red dot. Also it has the tri-rails mounted on the front of the grip, these too, are an option and don't come on the gun new. I'll throw in some 22lr ammo as well to get you going in the unlikely event you don't already have a 22lr gun.

This thing has fired every 22lr I have thrown at it. It runs excellently.

This is probably the best of the 'tacticool' 22s, in my opinion. 

Because of the cosmetic issue I'm going to let it go pretty cheap for a Sig 522. 

First $250 gets it. (They are $450+ New without said accessories.) This is ridiculously, horribly, unbelievably cheap.

Must be willing to meet within a 1hr drive of Steubenville (43952).

Must sell by tomorrow morning and as bad as I need to sell it I am not going one penny lower in price.

title: For Sale:  1939 Nambu Type 14 Japanease 8mm Luger
postcontent:
As the title says I am selling my Japanease Nambu type 14. It comes with the original leather holster, the original cleaning rod and two magazines. Unfortunitly the magazines serial numbers do not match the guns although the gun is all numbers matching. The finish on the gun is very good 90-95 percent, the action and trigger are smooth as butter! Here is a little more in depth info about this pistol : "This is a very special Type 14. The large trigger guard was introduced in Showa 14.9 (September, 1939) to allow the use of a gloved finger in cold climates. All guns made from then on had large trigger guards, regardless of where they were to see service. Then in 14.12 (December, 1939) they added the magazine retention spring on the lower front of the grip and switched from 25-groove to 17-groove grips. This pistol is one of the approximately 5,750 produced between 14.9 and 14.12 (September and December, 1939) that had the large trigger guard but no magazine retention spring. They are referred to as “transitional” variants, and most retain the 25-groove grips that were used on the older small trigger guard version"

I'm asking $900although no reasonable offer will be turned down. I couldn't upload pictures so please email me or text me for photos. REDACTED

WTS- AR with options!

I would like to sell the rifle as pictured with the following upgrades. If you want to lower the price I can remove/keep items (see "Options" below). Rifle started life as a 20" Oly plinkster. Its a 20" HBar contour barrel (rifle length gas system).

I used it this past year for one day of coyote hunting and seven 3gun competitions and am selling it only to fund the building of another very similar rifle.

Add-on's that stay with the rifle (i do not have the factory parts to replace these):
Factory case
Free float handguard
Low profile gas block
JP yellow trigger springs
Bravo Company bolt
PSA - H3 buffer
two - 30rd Thermold magazines
two- 20rd Thermold magazines

Arrendondo extended mag release $26
Nikon m223 1-4 optic with mount $320
JP Cooley Comp $90
Bravo Company charging handle $46
(if you choose to remove the comp, handle or mag release they can and will be replaced with the factory components)

Rifle price as pictured is: $1050
Rifle price bare bones (Minus the "options") : $650
I am located in St Paul, shoot at Oakdale on Thursdays and am working in StLouisPark the next few weeks so I can meet you anywhere out that way everyday but Thursdays.

I will sell the optic separate only once the rifle is gone. I will determine a price at that time if the rifle buyer does not want it. I am pretty firm on the price and but will consider trades and trades +cash (shotguns, ar's, .45, 9mm, 44mag pistols). The BCM bolt makes the gun extremely reliable as long as you keep it well lubricated (as I always have using Slip 2K EWL).
